titleStmt.title: [Aerial photograph showing the former site of Chota and Tanasee, 18th century Cherokee villages] / [by Wayne D. Roberts]: a machine-readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Roberts, Wayne D.

availability.p: This work is the property of the McClung Museum, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN. It may be used freely by individuals for research, teaching, and personal use as long as this statement of availability is included in the text.

bibl.title: [Aerial photograph showing the former site of Chota and Tanasee, 18th century Cherokee villages] / [by Wayne D. Roberts]
bibl.author: Roberts, Wayne D.
bibl.note: This aerial photograph shows the former site of Chota and Tanasee, 18th century Overhill Cherokee villages in the Little Tennessee River Valley. Chota was recognized by Native Americans and European settlers as a powerful social and economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. The University of Tennessee conducted excavations of Overhill Cherokee villages between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River Valley by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA).
Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

projectDesc.p: Prepared for The University of Tennessee Digital Library

Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with Microsoft Word spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.
